description:
Hippopotamus amphibius kiboko, commonly known as the Nile hippopotamus or the Kiboko hippopotamus, is a subspecies of the common hippopotamus (Hippopotamus amphibius) found in East Africa, particularly in the Nile River basin.

The Nile hippopotamus is a large, semi-aquatic mammal that spends much of its time in the water, such as rivers, lakes, and swamps. It has a distinctive barrel-shaped body, short legs, and a large, wide-open mouth with large canine teeth. The skin of the Nile hippopotamus is thick and gray-brown in color, with a slight pinkish hue.

This subspecies is adapted to an amphibious lifestyle, with the ability to hold its breath for up to five minutes while submerged in water. It is an herbivorous species, feeding primarily on grasses, aquatic plants, and other vegetation found near its aquatic habitats.

The Nile hippopotamus is known for its social behavior, living in groups called "herds" or "pods" led by a dominant male. These groups typically consist of females, their offspring, and a few younger males. The Nile hippopotamus is considered a vulnerable species due to habitat loss, poaching, and conflicts with human populations.
